parents.@parents-0: You know who your parents are or were.
parents.@parents-1: You do not know who your parents were.

mixedparents.@halfelfparents-0: One parent was an elf and the other was a human.
mixedparents.@halfelfparents-1: One parent was an elf and the other was a half-elf.
mixedparents.@halfelfparents-2: One parent was a human and the other was a half-elf.
mixedparents.@halforcparents-0: One parent was an orc and the other was a human.
mixedparents.@halforcparents-1: One parent was an orc and the other was a half-orc.
mixedparents.@halforcparents-2: One parent was a human and the other was a half-orc.
mixedparents.@tieflingparents-0: Both parents were humans, their infernal heritage dormant until you came along.
mixedparents.@tieflingparents-1: One parent was a tiefling and the other was a human.
mixedparents.@tieflingparents-2: One parent was a tiefling and the other was a devil.
mixedparents.@tieflingparents-3: One parent was a human and the other was a devil.

birthplace.@birthplace-2: Home of a healer or midwife
birthplace.@birthplace-14: Among people of a different race
birthplace.@birthplace-15: On board a boat or a ship
birthplace.@birthplace-16: In a prison or in the headquarters of a secret organization
birthplace.@birthplace-20: On the Astral Plane or the Ethereal Plane
birthplace.@birthplace-21: On an Inner Plane of your choice
birthplace.@birthplace-22: On an Outer Plane of your choice

family.@family-5: Paternal or maternal aunt, uncle, or both; or extended family such as a tribe or clan

absentparent.@absentparent-0: Your parent died (roll on the Cause of Death supplemental table).
absentparent.@absentparent-1: Your parent was imprisoned, enslaved, or otherwise taken away.
absentparent.@absentparent-3: Your parent disappeared to an unknown fate.

home.@home-2: No permanent residence; you moved around a lot
home.@home-3: Encampment or village in the wilderness

memories.@memories-0: I am still haunted by my childhood, when I was treated badly by my peers.
memories.@memories-1: I spent most of my childhood alone, with no close friends.
memories.@memories-2: Others saw me as being different or strange, and so I had few companions.
memories.@memories-3: I had a few close friends and lived an ordinary childhood.
memories.@memories-4: I had several friends, and my childhood was generally a happy one.
memories.@memories-5: I always found it easy to make friends, and I loved being around people.
memories.@memories-6: Everyone knew who I was, and I had friends everywhere I went.

class.@barbarian-0: My devotion to my people lifted me in battle, making me powerful and dangerous.
class.@barbarian-1: The spirits of my ancestors called on me to carry out a great task.
class.@barbarian-2: I lost control in battle one day, and it was as if something else was manipulating my body, forcing it to kill every foe I could reach.
class.@barbarian-3: I went on a spiritual journey to find myself and instead found a spirit animal to guide, protect, and inspire me.
class.@barbarian-4: I was struck by lightning and lived. Afterward, I found a new strength within me that let me push beyond my limitations.
class.@barbarian-5: My anger needed to be channeled into battle, or I risked becoming an indiscriminate killer.
class.@bard-0: I awakened my latent bardic abilities through trial and error.
class.@bard-1: I was a gifted performer and attracted the attention of a master bard who schooled me in the old techniques.
class.@bard-2: I joined a loose society of scholars and orators to learn new techniques of performance and magic.
class.@bard-3: I felt a calling to recount the deeds of champions and heroes, to bring them alive in song and story.
class.@bard-4: I joined one of the great colleges to learn old lore, the secrets of magic, and the art of performance.
class.@bard-5: I picked up a musical instrument one day and instantly discovered that I could play it.
class.@cleric-0: A supernatural being in service to the gods called me to become a divine agent in the world.
class.@cleric-1: I saw the injustice and horror in the world and felt moved to take a stand against them.
class.@cleric-2: My god gave me an unmistakable sign. I dropped everything to serve the divine.
class.@cleric-3: Although I was always devout, it wasn’t until I completed a pilgrimage that I knew my true calling.
class.@cleric-4: I used to serve in my religion’s bureaucracy but found I needed to work in the world, to bring the message of my faith to the darkest corners of the land.
class.@cleric-5: I realize that my god works through me, and I do as commanded, even though I don’t know why I was chosen to serve.
class.@druid-0: I saw too much devastation in the wild places, too much of nature’s splendor ruined by the despoilers. I joined a circle of druids to fight back against the enemies of nature.
class.@druid-1: I found a place among a group of druids after I fled a catastrophe.
class.@druid-2: I have always had an affinity for animals, so I explored my talent to see how I could best use it.
class.@druid-3: I befriended a druid and was moved by druidic teachings. I decided to follow my friend’s guidance and give something back to the world.
class.@druid-4: While I was growing up, I saw spirits all around me — entities no one else could perceive. I sought out the druids to help me understand the visions and communicate with these beings.
class.@druid-5: I have always felt disgust for creatures of unnatural origin. For this reason, I immersed myself in the study of the druidic mysteries and became a champion of the natural order.
class.@fighter-0: I wanted to hone my combat skills, and so I joined a war college.
class.@fighter-1: I squired for a knight who taught me how to fight, care for a steed, and conduct myself with honor. I decided to take up that path for myself.
class.@fighter-2: Horrible monsters descended on my community, killing someone I loved. I took up arms to destroy those creatures and others of a similar nature.
class.@fighter-3: I joined the army and learned how to fight as part of a group.
class.@fighter-4: I grew up fighting, and I refined my talents by defending myself against people who crossed me.
class.@fighter-5: I could always pick up just about any weapon and know how to use it effectively.
class.@monk-0: I was chosen to study at a secluded monastery. There, I was taught the fundamental techniques required to eventually master a tradition.
class.@monk-1: I sought instruction to gain a deeper understanding of existence and my place in the world.
class.@monk-2: I stumbled into a portal to the Shadowfell and took refuge in a strange monastery, where I learned how to defend myself against the forces of darkness.
class.@monk-3: I was overwhelmed with grief after losing someone close to me, and I sought the advice of philosophers to help me cope with my loss.
class.@monk-4: I could feel that a special sort of power lay within me, so I sought out those who could help me call it forth and master it.
class.@monk-5: I was wild and undisciplined as a youngster, but then I realized the error of my ways. I applied to a monastery and became a monk as a way to live a life of discipline.
class.@paladin-0: A fantastical being appeared before me and called on me to undertake a holy quest.
class.@paladin-1: One of my ancestors left a holy quest unfulfilled, so I intend to finish that work.
class.@paladin-2: The world is a dark and terrible place. I decided to serve as a beacon of light shining out against the gathering shadows.
class.@paladin-3: I served as a paladin’s squire, learning all I needed to swear my own sacred oath.
class.@paladin-4: Evil must be opposed on all fronts. I feel compelled to seek out wickedness and purge it from the world.
class.@paladin-5: Becoming a paladin was a natural consequence of my unwavering faith. In taking my vows, I became the holy sword of my religion.
class.@ranger-0: I found purpose while I honed my hunting skills by bringing down dangerous animals at the edge of civilization.
class.@ranger-1: I always had a way with animals, able to calm them with a soothing word and a touch.
class.@ranger-2: I suffer from terrible wanderlust, so being a ranger gave me a reason not to remain in one place for too long.
class.@ranger-3: I have seen what happens when the monsters come out from the dark. I took it upon myself to become the first line of defense against the evils that lie beyond civilization’s borders.
class.@ranger-4: I met a grizzled ranger who taught me woodcraft and the secrets of the wild lands.
class.@ranger-5: I served in an army, learning the precepts of my profession while blazing trails and scouting enemy encampments.
class.@rogue-0: I’ve always been nimble and quick of wit, so I decided to use those talents to help me make my way in the world.
class.@rogue-1: An assassin or a thief wronged me, so I focused my training on mastering the skills of my enemy to better combat foes of that sort.
class.@rogue-2: An experienced rogue saw something in me and taught me several useful tricks.
class.@rogue-3: I decided to turn my natural lucky streak into the basis of a career, though I still realize that improving my skills is essential.
class.@rogue-4: I took up with a group of ruffians who showed me how to get what I want through sneakiness rather than direct confrontation.
class.@rogue-5: I’m a sucker for a shiny bauble or a sack of coins, as long as I can get my hands on it without risking life and limb.
class.@sorcerer-0: When I was born, all the water in the house froze solid, the milk spoiled, or all the iron turned to copper. My family is convinced that this event was a harbinger of stranger things to come for me.
class.@sorcerer-1: I suffered a terrible emotional or physical strain, which brought forth my latent magical power. I have fought to control it ever since.
class.@sorcerer-2: My immediate family never spoke of my ancestors, and when I asked, they would change the subject. It wasn’t until I started displaying strange talents that the full truth of my heritage came out.
class.@sorcerer-3: When a monster threatened one of my friends, I became filled with anxiety. I lashed out instinctively and blasted the wretched thing with a force that came from within me.
class.@sorcerer-4: Sensing something special in me, a stranger taught me how to control my gift.
class.@sorcerer-5: After I escaped from a magical conflagration, I realized that though I was unharmed, I was not unchanged. I began to exhibit unusual abilities that I am just beginning to understand.
class.@warlock-0: While wandering around in a forbidden place, I encountered an otherworldly being that offered to enter into a pact with me.
class.@warlock-1: I was examining a strange tome I found in an abandoned library when the entity that would become my patron suddenly appeared before me.
class.@warlock-2: I stumbled into the clutches of my patron after I accidentally stepped through a magical doorway.
class.@warlock-3: When I was faced with a terrible crisis, I prayed to any being who would listen, and the creature that answered became my patron.
class.@warlock-4: My future patron visited me in my dreams and offered great power in exchange for my service.
class.@warlock-5: One of my ancestors had a pact with my patron, so that entity was determined to bind me to the same agreement.
class.@wizard-0: An old wizard chose me from among several candidates to serve an apprenticeship.
class.@wizard-1: When I became lost in a forest, a hedge wizard found me, took me in, and taught me the rudiments of magic.
class.@wizard-2: I grew up listening to tales of great wizards and knew I wanted to follow their path. I strove to be accepted at an academy of magic and succeeded.
class.@wizard-3: One of my relatives was an accomplished wizard who decided I was smart enough to learn the craft.
class.@wizard-4: While exploring an old tomb, library, or temple, I found a spellbook. I was immediately driven to learn all I could about becoming a wizard.
class.@wizard-5: I was a prodigy who demonstrated mastery of the arcane arts at an early age. When I became old enough to set out on my own, I did so to learn more magic and expand my power.

background.@acolyte-0: I ran away from home at an early age and found refuge in a temple.
background.@acolyte-1: My family gave me to a temple, since they were unable or unwilling to care for me.
background.@acolyte-2: I grew up in a household with strong religious convictions. Entering the service of one or more gods seemed natural.
background.@acolyte-3: An impassioned sermon struck a chord deep in my soul and moved me to serve the faith.
background.@acolyte-4: I followed a childhood friend, a respected acquaintance, or someone I loved into religious service.
background.@acolyte-5: After encountering a true servant of the gods, I was so inspired that I immediately entered the service of a religious group.
background.@charlatan-0: I was left to my own devices, and my knack for manipulating others helped me survive.
background.@charlatan-1: I learned early on that people are gullible and easy to exploit.
background.@charlatan-2: I often got in trouble, but I managed to talk my way out of it every time.
background.@charlatan-3: I took up with a confidence artist, from whom I learned my craft.
background.@charlatan-4: After a charlatan fleeced my family, I decided to learn the trade so I would never be fooled by such deception again.
background.@charlatan-5: I was poor or I feared becoming poor, so I learned the tricks I needed to keep myself out of poverty.
background.@criminal-0: I resented authority in my younger days and saw a life of crime as the best way to fight against tyranny and oppression.
background.@criminal-1: Necessity forced me to take up the life, since it was the only way I could survive.
background.@criminal-2: I fell in with a gang of reprobates and ne’er-do-wells, and I learned my specialty from them.
background.@criminal-3: A parent or relative taught me my criminal specialty to prepare me for the family business.
background.@criminal-4: I left home and found a place in a thieves’ guild or some other criminal organization.
background.@criminal-5: I was always bored, so I turned to crime to pass the time and discovered I was quite good at it.
background.@entertainer-0: Members of my family made ends meet by performing, so it was fitting for me to follow their example.
background.@entertainer-1: I always had a keen insight into other people, enough so that I could make them laugh or cry with my stories or songs.
background.@entertainer-2: I ran away from home to follow a minstrel troupe.
background.@entertainer-3: I saw a bard perform once, and I knew from that moment on what I was born to do.
background.@entertainer-4: I earned coin by performing on street corners and eventually made a name for myself.
background.@entertainer-5: A traveling entertainer took me in and taught me the trade.
background.@folkhero-0: I learned what was right and wrong from my family.
background.@folkhero-1: I was always enamored by tales of heroes and wished I could be something more than ordinary.
background.@folkhero-2: I hated my mundane life, so when it was time for someone to step up and do the right thing, I took my chance.
background.@folkhero-3: A parent or one of my relatives was an adventurer, and I was inspired by that person’s courage.
background.@folkhero-4: A mad old hermit spoke a prophecy when I was born, saying that I would accomplish great things.
background.@folkhero-5: I have always stood up for those who are weaker than I am.
background.@gladiator-0: I was captured and forced to fight in the arena to survive.
background.@gladiator-1: I grew up idolizing famous gladiators and sought to become one myself.
background.@gladiator-2: My tribe or hometown had a long tradition of gladiatorial combat, and I was chosen to represent them.
background.@gladiator-3: I needed money to pay off a debt and found that fighting in the arena was the quickest way to earn it.
background.@gladiator-4: I was framed for a crime and given a choice between rotting in prison or fighting in the pits.
background.@gladiator-5: I was trained as a warrior but found that the glory and excitement of the arena drew me more than the battlefield.
background.@guildartisan-0: I was apprenticed to a master who taught me the guild’s business.
background.@guildartisan-1: I helped a guild artisan keep a secret or complete a task, and in return I was taken on as an apprentice.
background.@guildartisan-2: One of my family members who belonged to the guild made a place for me.
background.@guildartisan-3: I was always good with my hands, so I took the opportunity to learn a trade.
background.@guildartisan-4: I wanted to get away from my home situation and start a new life.
background.@guildartisan-5: I learned the essentials of my craft from a mentor but had to join the guild to finish my training.
background.@hermit-0: My enemies ruined my reputation, and I fled to the wilds to avoid further disparagement.
background.@hermit-1: I am comfortable with being isolated, as I seek inner peace.
background.@hermit-2: I never liked the people I called my friends, so it was easy for me to strike out on my own.
background.@hermit-3: I felt compelled to forsake my past, but did so with great reluctance, and sometimes I regret making that decision.
background.@hermit-4: I lost everything — my home, my family, my friends. Going it alone was all I could do.
background.@hermit-5: Society’s decadence disgusted me, so I decided to leave it behind.
background.@knight-0: I was born into a noble family and knighthood was expected of me as part of my duty.
background.@knight-1: I squired for a great knight and eventually earned my own title through service and loyalty.
background.@knight-2: I sought to uphold a code of honor and protect the weak, and knighthood was the best way to fulfill that calling.
background.@knight-3: My family’s estate was in ruin, and I took up knighthood to restore our honor and name.
background.@knight-4: I won my knighthood in a grand tournament, earning respect and recognition for my skills.
background.@knight-5: I swore an oath to a liege lord or religious order, vowing to protect their lands or serve their cause as a knight.
background.@noble-0: I come from an old and storied family, and it fell to me to preserve the family name.
background.@noble-1: My family has been disgraced, and I intend to clear our name.
background.@noble-2: My family recently came by its title, and that elevation thrust us into a new and strange world.
background.@noble-3: My family has a title, but none of my ancestors have distinguished themselves since we gained it.
background.@noble-4: My family is filled with remarkable people. I hope to live up to their example.
background.@noble-5: I hope to increase my family’s power and influence.
background.@outlander-0: I spent a lot of time in the wilderness as a youngster, and I came to love that way of life.
background.@outlander-1: From a young age, I couldn’t abide the stink of the cities and preferred to spend my time in nature.
background.@outlander-2: I came to understand the darkness that lurks in the wilds, and I vowed to combat it.
background.@outlander-3: My people lived on the edges of civilization, and I learned the methods of survival from my family.
background.@outlander-4: After a tragedy I retreated to the wilderness, leaving my old life behind.
background.@outlander-5: My family moved away from civilization, and I learned to adapt to my new environment.
background.@pirate-0: I was press-ganged into service aboard a pirate ship and eventually embraced the life of freedom on the high seas.
background.@pirate-1: I grew up in a coastal town where piracy was a way of life, and joining a crew was the natural path for me.
background.@pirate-2: I was a sailor on a merchant vessel that was taken by pirates, and I joined them rather than be killed or left adrift.
background.@pirate-3: I sought revenge against a corrupt navy or government, and piracy gave me the power to strike back.
background.@pirate-4: I loved the thrill of adventure and saw piracy as the ultimate escape from a dull, ordinary life.
background.@pirate-5: A pirate captain took me under their wing, teaching me the ways of the sea and the freedom it offered.
background.@sage-0: I was naturally curious, so I packed up and went to a university to learn more about the world.
background.@sage-1: My mentor’s teachings opened my mind to new possibilities in that field of study.
background.@sage-2: I was always an avid reader, and I learned much about my favorite topic on my own.
background.@sage-3: I discovered an old library and pored over the texts I found there. That experience awakened a hunger for more knowledge.
background.@sage-4: I impressed a wizard who told me I was squandering my talents and should seek out an education to take advantage of my gifts.
background.@sage-5: One of my parents or a relative gave me a basic education that whetted my appetite, and I left home to build on what I had learned.
background.@sailor-0: I was press-ganged by pirates and forced to serve on their ship until I finally escaped.
background.@sailor-1: I wanted to see the world, so I signed on as a deckhand for a merchant ship.
background.@sailor-2: One of my relatives was a sailor who took me to sea.
background.@sailor-3: I needed to escape my community quickly, so I stowed away on a ship. When the crew found me, I was forced to work for my passage.
background.@sailor-4: Reavers attacked my community, so I found refuge on a ship until I could seek vengeance.
background.@sailor-5: I had few prospects where I was living, so I left to find my fortune elsewhere.
background.@soldier-0: I joined the militia to help protect my community from monsters.
background.@soldier-1: A relative of mine was a soldier, and I wanted to carry on the family tradition.
background.@soldier-2: The local lord forced me to enlist in the army.
background.@soldier-3: War ravaged my homeland while I was growing up. Fighting was the only life I ever knew.
background.@soldier-4: I wanted fame and fortune, so I joined a mercenary company, selling my sword to the highest bidder.
background.@soldier-5: Invaders attacked my homeland. It was my duty to take up arms in defense of my people.
background.@urchin-0: Wanderlust caused me to leave my family to see the world. I look after myself.
background.@urchin-1: I ran away from a bad situation at home and made my own way in the world.
background.@urchin-2: Monsters wiped out my village, and I was the sole survivor. I had to find a way to survive.
background.@urchin-3: A notorious thief looked after me and other orphans, and we spied and stole to earn our keep.
background.@urchin-4: One day I woke up on the streets, alone and hungry, with no memory of my early childhood.
background.@urchin-5: My parents died, leaving no one to look after me. I raised myself.

personality.@acolyte-traits-0: I idolize a particular hero of my faith, and constantly refer to that person’s deeds and example.
personality.@acolyte-traits-1: I can find common ground between the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace.
personality.@acolyte-traits-2: I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen.
personality.@acolyte-traits-3: Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude.
personality.@acolyte-traits-4: I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
personality.@acolyte-traits-5: I am tolerant (or intolerant) of other faiths and respect (or condemn) the worship of other gods.
personality.@acolyte-traits-6: I’ve enjoyed fine food, drink, and high society among my temple’s elite. Rough living grates on me.
personality.@acolyte-traits-7: I’ve spent so long in the temple that I have little practical experience dealing with people in the outside world.
personality.@acolyte-ideals-0: Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)
personality.@acolyte-ideals-1: Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. (Good)
personality.@acolyte-ideals-2: Change. We must help bring about the changes the gods are constantly working in the world. (Chaotic)
personality.@acolyte-ideals-3: Power. I hope to one day rise to the top of my faith’s religious hierarchy. (Lawful)
personality.@acolyte-ideals-4: Faith. I trust that my deity will guide my actions. I have faith that if I work hard, things will go well. (Lawful)
personality.@acolyte-ideals-5: Aspiration. I seek to prove myself worthy of my god’s favor by matching my actions against his or her teachings. (Any)
personality.@acolyte-bonds-0: I would die to recover an ancient relic of my faith that was lost long ago.
personality.@acolyte-bonds-1: I will someday get revenge on the corrupt temple hierarchy who branded me a heretic.
personality.@acolyte-bonds-2: I owe my life to the priest who took me in when my parents died.
personality.@acolyte-bonds-3: Everything I do is for the common people.
personality.@acolyte-bonds-4: I will do anything to protect the temple where I served.
personality.@acolyte-bonds-5: I seek to preserve a sacred text that my enemies consider heretical and seek to destroy.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-0: I judge others harshly, and myself even more severely.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-1: I put too much trust in those who wield power within my temple’s hierarchy.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-2: My piety sometimes leads me to blindly trust those that profess faith in my god.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-3: I am inflexible in my thinking.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-4: I am suspicious of strangers and expect the worst of them.
personality.@acolyte-flaws-5: Once I pick a goal, I become obsessed with it to the detriment of everything else in my life.
personality.@charlatan-traits-0: I fall in and out of love easily, and am always pursuing someone.
personality.@charlatan-traits-1: I have a joke for every occasion, especially occasions where humor is inappropriate.
personality.@charlatan-traits-2: Flattery is my preferred trick for getting what I want.
personality.@charlatan-traits-3: I’m a born gambler who can’t resist taking a risk for a potential payoff.
personality.@charlatan-traits-4: I lie about almost everything, even when there’s no good reason to.
personality.@charlatan-traits-5: Sarcasm and insults are my weapons of choice.
personality.@charlatan-traits-6: I keep multiple holy symbols on me and invoke whatever deity might come in useful at any given moment.
personality.@charlatan-traits-7: I pocket anything I see that might have some value.
personality.@charlatan-ideals-0: Independence. I am a free spirit—no one tells me what to do. (Chaotic)
personality.@charlatan-ideals-1: Fairness. I never target people who can’t afford to lose a few coins. (Lawful)
personality.@charlatan-ideals-2: Charity. I distribute the money I acquire to the people who really need it. (Good)
personality.@charlatan-ideals-3: Creativity. I never run the same con twice. (Chaotic)
personality.@charlatan-ideals-4: Friendship. Material goods come and go. Bonds of friendship last forever. (Good)
personality.@charlatan-ideals-5: Aspiration. I’m determined to make something of myself. (Any)
personality.@charlatan-bonds-0: I fleeced the wrong person and must work to ensure that this individual never crosses paths with me or those I care about.
personality.@charlatan-bonds-1: I owe everything to my mentor—a horrible person who’s probably rotting in jail somewhere.
personality.@charlatan-bonds-2: Somewhere out there, I have a child who doesn’t know me. I’m making the world better for him or her.
personality.@charlatan-bonds-3: I come from a noble family, and one day I’ll reclaim my lands and title from those who stole them from me.
personality.@charlatan-bonds-4: A powerful person killed someone I love. Some day soon, I’ll have my revenge.
personality.@charlatan-bonds-5: I swindled and ruined a person who didn’t deserve it. I seek to atone for my misdeeds but might never be able to forgive myself.
personality.@charlatan-flaws-0: I can’t resist a pretty face.
personality.@charlatan-flaws-1: I’m always in debt. I spend my ill-gotten gains on decadent luxuries faster than I bring them in...
personality.@charlatan-flaws-2: I’m convinced that no one could ever fool me the way I fool others.
personality.@charlatan-flaws-3: I’m too greedy for my own good. I can’t resist taking a risk if there’s money involved.
personality.@charlatan-flaws-4: I can’t resist swindling people who are more powerful than me.
personality.@charlatan-flaws-5: I hate to admit it and will hate myself for it, but I’ll run and preserve my own hide if the going gets tough.
personality.@criminal-traits-0: I always have a plan for what to do when things go wrong.
personality.@criminal-traits-1: I am always calm, no matter what the situation. I never raise my voice or let my emotions control me.
personality.@criminal-traits-2: The first thing I do in a new place is note the locations of everything valuable—or where such things could be hidden.
personality.@criminal-traits-3: I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy.
personality.@criminal-traits-4: I am incredibly slow to trust. Those who seem the fairest often have the most to hide.
personality.@criminal-traits-5: I don’t pay attention to the risks in a situation. Never tell me the odds.
personality.@criminal-traits-6: The best way to get me to do something is to tell me I can’t do it.
personality.@criminal-traits-7: I blow up at the slightest insult.
personality.@criminal-ideals-0: Honor. I don’t steal from others in the trade. (Lawful)
personality.@criminal-ideals-1: Freedom. Chains are meant to be broken, as are those who would forge them. (Chaotic)
personality.@criminal-ideals-2: Charity. I steal from the wealthy so that I can help people in need. (Good)
personality.@criminal-ideals-3: Greed. I will do whatever it takes to become wealthy. (Evil)
personality.@criminal-ideals-4: People. I’m loyal to my friends, not to any ideals, and everyone else can take a trip down the Styx for all I care. (Neutral)
personality.@criminal-ideals-5: Redemption. There’s a spark of good in everyone. (Good)
personality.@criminal-bonds-0: I’m trying to pay off an old debt I owe to a generous benefactor.
personality.@criminal-bonds-1: My ill-gotten gains go to support my family.
personality.@criminal-bonds-2: Something important was taken from me, and I aim to steal it back.
personality.@criminal-bonds-3: I will become the greatest thief that ever lived.
personality.@criminal-bonds-4: I’m guilty of a terrible crime. I hope I can redeem myself for it.
personality.@criminal-bonds-5: Someone I loved died because of a mistake I made. That will never happen again.
personality.@criminal-flaws-0: When I see something valuable, I can’t think about anything but how to steal it.
personality.@criminal-flaws-1: When faced with a choice between money and my friends, I usually choose the money.
personality.@criminal-flaws-2: If there’s a plan, I’ll forget it. If I don’t forget it, I’ll ignore it.
personality.@criminal-flaws-3: I have a “tell” that reveals when I’m lying.
personality.@criminal-flaws-4: I turn tail and run when things look bad.
personality.@criminal-flaws-5: An innocent person is in prison for a crime that I committed. I’m okay with that.
personality.@entertainer-traits-0: I know a story relevant to almost every situation.
personality.@entertainer-traits-1: Whenever I come to a new place, I collect local rumors and spread gossip.
personality.@entertainer-traits-2: I’m a hopeless romantic, always searching for that “special someone.”
personality.@entertainer-traits-3: Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension.
personality.@entertainer-traits-4: I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
personality.@entertainer-traits-5: I get bitter if I’m not the center of attention.
personality.@entertainer-traits-6: I’ll settle for nothing less than perfection.
personality.@entertainer-traits-7: I change my mood or my mind as quickly as I change key in a song.
personality.@entertainer-ideals-0: Beauty. When I perform, I make the world better than it was. (Good)
personality.@entertainer-ideals-1: Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)
personality.@entertainer-ideals-2: Creativity. The world is in need of new ideas and bold action. (Chaotic)
personality.@entertainer-ideals-3: Greed. I’m only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
personality.@entertainer-ideals-4: People. I like seeing the smiles on people’s faces when I perform. That’s all that matters. (Neutral)
personality.@entertainer-ideals-5: Honesty. Art should reflect the soul; it should come from within and reveal who we really are. (Any)
personality.@entertainer-bonds-0: My instrument is my most treasured possession, and it reminds me of someone I love.
personality.@entertainer-bonds-1: Someone stole my precious instrument, and someday I’ll get it back.
personality.@entertainer-bonds-2: I want to be famous, whatever it takes.
personality.@entertainer-bonds-3: I idolize a hero of the old tales and measure my deeds against that person’s.
personality.@entertainer-bonds-4: I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
personality.@entertainer-bonds-5: I would do anything for the other members of my old troupe.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-0: I’ll do anything to win fame and renown.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-1: I’m a sucker for a pretty face.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-2: A scandal prevents me from ever going home again. That kind of trouble seems to follow me around.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-3: I once satirized a noble who still wants my head. It was a mistake that I will likely repeat.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-4: I have trouble keeping my true feelings hidden. My sharp tongue lands me in trouble.
personality.@entertainer-flaws-5: Despite my best efforts, I am unreliable to my friends.
personality.@folkhero-traits-0: I judge people by their actions, not their words.
personality.@folkhero-traits-1: If someone is in trouble, I’m always ready to lend help.
personality.@folkhero-traits-2: When I set my mind to something, I follow through no matter what gets in my way.
personality.@folkhero-traits-3: I have a strong sense of fair play and always try to find the most equitable solution to arguments.
personality.@folkhero-traits-4: I’m confident in my own abilities and do what I can to instill confidence in others.
personality.@folkhero-traits-5: Thinking is for other people. I prefer action.
personality.@folkhero-traits-6: I misuse long words in an attempt to sound smarter.
personality.@folkhero-traits-7: I get bored easily. When am I going to get on with my destiny?
personality.@folkhero-ideals-0: Respect. People deserve to be treated with dignity and respect. (Good)
personality.@folkhero-ideals-1: Fairness. No one should get preferential treatment before the law, and no one is above the law. (Lawful)
personality.@folkhero-ideals-2: Freedom. Tyrants must not be allowed to oppress the people. (Chaotic)
personality.@folkhero-ideals-3: Might. If I become strong, I can take what I want—what I deserve. (Evil)
personality.@folkhero-ideals-4: Sincerity. There’s no good in pretending to be something I’m not. (Neutral)
personality.@folkhero-ideals-5: Destiny. Nothing and no one can steer me away from my higher calling. (Any)
personality.@folkhero-bonds-0: I have a family, but I have no idea where they are. One day, I hope to see them again.
personality.@folkhero-bonds-1: I worked the land, I love the land, and I will protect the land.
personality.@folkhero-bonds-2: A proud noble once gave me a horrible beating, and I will take my revenge on any bully I encounter.
personality.@folkhero-bonds-3: My tools are symbols of my past life, and I carry them so that I will never forget my roots.
personality.@folkhero-bonds-4: I protect those who cannot protect themselves.
personality.@folkhero-bonds-5: I wish my childhood sweetheart had come with me to pursue my destiny.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-0: The tyrant who rules my land will stop at nothing to see me killed.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-1: I’m convinced of the significance of my destiny, and blind to my shortcomings and the risk of failure.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-2: The people who knew me when I was young know my shameful secret, so I can never go home again.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-3: I have a weakness for the vices of the city, especially hard drink.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-4: Secretly, I believe that things would be better if I were a tyrant lording over the land.
personality.@folkhero-flaws-5: I have trouble trusting in my allies.
personality.@gladiator-traits-0: I know a story relevant to almost every situation.
personality.@gladiator-traits-1: Whenever I come to a new place, I collect local rumors and spread gossip.
personality.@gladiator-traits-2: I’m a hopeless romantic, always searching for that “special someone.”
personality.@gladiator-traits-3: Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension.
personality.@gladiator-traits-4: I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
personality.@gladiator-traits-5: I get bitter if I’m not the center of attention.
personality.@gladiator-traits-6: I’ll settle for nothing less than perfection.
personality.@gladiator-traits-7: I change my mood or my mind as quickly as I change key in a song.
personality.@gladiator-ideals-0: Beauty. When I perform, I make the world better than it was. (Good)
personality.@gladiator-ideals-1: Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)
personality.@gladiator-ideals-2: Creativity. The world is in need of new ideas and bold action. (Chaotic)
personality.@gladiator-ideals-3: Greed. I’m only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
personality.@gladiator-ideals-4: People. I like seeing the smiles on people’s faces when I perform. That’s all that matters. (Neutral)
personality.@gladiator-ideals-5: Honesty. Art should reflect the soul; it should come from within and reveal who we really are. (Any)
personality.@gladiator-bonds-0: My instrument is my most treasured possession, and it reminds me of someone I love.
personality.@gladiator-bonds-1: Someone stole my precious instrument, and someday I’ll get it back.
personality.@gladiator-bonds-2: I want to be famous, whatever it takes.
personality.@gladiator-bonds-3: I idolize a hero of the old tales and measure my deeds against that person’s.
personality.@gladiator-bonds-4: I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
personality.@gladiator-bonds-5: I would do anything for the other members of my old troupe.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-0: I’ll do anything to win fame and renown.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-1: I’m a sucker for a pretty face.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-2: A scandal prevents me from ever going home again. That kind of trouble seems to follow me around.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-3: I once satirized a noble who still wants my head. It was a mistake that I will likely repeat.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-4: I have trouble keeping my true feelings hidden. My sharp tongue lands me in trouble.
personality.@gladiator-flaws-5: Despite my best efforts, I am unreliable to my friends.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-0: I believe that anything worth doing is worth doing right. I can’t help it—I’m a perfectionist.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-1: I’m a snob who looks down on those who can’t appreciate fine art.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-2: I always want to know how things work and what makes people tick.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-3: I’m full of witty aphorisms and have a proverb for every occasion.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-4: I’m rude to people who lack my commitment to hard work and fair play.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-5: I like to talk at length about my profession.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-6: I don’t part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
personality.@guildartisan-traits-7: I’m well known for my work, and I want to make sure everyone appreciates it. I’m always taken aback when people haven’t heard of me.
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-0: Community. It is the duty of all people to strengthen the bonds and security of communities. (Lawful)
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-1: Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-2: Freedom. Everyone should be free to pursue his or her own livelihood. (Chaotic)
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-3: Greed. I’m only in it for the money. (Evil)
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-4: People. I’m committed to the people I care about, not to ideals. (Neutral)
personality.@guildartisan-ideals-5: Aspiration. I work hard to be the best there is at my craft. (Any)
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-0: The workshop where I learned my trade is the most important place in the world to me.
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-1: I created a great work for someone, and then found them unworthy to receive it. I’m still looking for someone worthy.
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-2: I owe my guild a great debt for forging me into the person I am today.
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-3: I pursue wealth to secure someone’s love.
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-4: One day I will return to my guild and prove that I am the greatest artisan of them all.
personality.@guildartisan-bonds-5: I will get revenge on the evil forces that destroyed my place of business and ruined my livelihood.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-0: I’ll do anything to get my hands on something rare or priceless.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-1: I’m quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-2: No one must ever learn that I once stole money from guild coffers.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-3: I’m never satisfied with what I have—I always want more.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-4: I would kill to acquire a noble title.
personality.@guildartisan-flaws-5: I’m horribly jealous of anyone who can outshine my handiwork. Everywhere I go, I’m surrounded by rivals.
personality.@hermit-traits-0: I’ve been isolated for so long that I rarely speak, preferring gestures and the occasional grunt.
personality.@hermit-traits-1: I am utterly serene, even in the face of disaster.
personality.@hermit-traits-2: The leader of my community had something wise to say on every topic, and I am eager to share that wisdom.
personality.@hermit-traits-3: I feel tremendous empathy for all who suffer.
personality.@hermit-traits-4: I’m oblivious to etiquette and social expectations.
personality.@hermit-traits-5: I connect everything that happens to me to a grand, cosmic plan.
personality.@hermit-traits-6: I often get lost in my own thoughts and contemplation, becoming oblivious to my surroundings.
personality.@hermit-traits-7: I am working on a grand philosophical theory and love sharing my ideas.
personality.@hermit-ideals-0: Greater Good. My gifts are meant to be shared with all, not used for my own benefit. (Good)
personality.@hermit-ideals-1: Logic. Emotions must not cloud our sense of what is right and true, or our logical thinking. (Lawful)
personality.@hermit-ideals-2: Free Thinking. Inquiry and curiosity are the pillars of progress. (Chaotic)
personality.@hermit-ideals-3: Power. Solitude and contemplation are paths toward mystical or magical power. (Evil)
personality.@hermit-ideals-4: Live and Let Live. Meddling in the affairs of others only causes trouble. (Neutral)
personality.@hermit-ideals-5: Self-Knowledge. If you know yourself, there’s nothing left to know. (Any)
personality.@hermit-bonds-0: Nothing is more important than the other members of my hermitage, order, or association.
personality.@hermit-bonds-1: I entered seclusion to hide from the ones who might still be hunting me. I must someday confront them.
personality.@hermit-bonds-2: I’m still seeking the enlightenment I pursued in my seclusion, and it still eludes me.
personality.@hermit-bonds-3: I entered seclusion because I loved someone I could not have.
personality.@hermit-bonds-4: Should my discovery come to light, it could bring ruin to the world.
personality.@hermit-bonds-5: My isolation gave me great insight into a great evil that only I can destroy.
personality.@hermit-flaws-0: Now that I’ve returned to the world, I enjoy its delights a little too much.
personality.@hermit-flaws-1: I harbor bloodthirsty thoughts that my isolation and meditation failed to quell.
personality.@hermit-flaws-2: I am dogmatic in my thoughts and philosophy.
personality.@hermit-flaws-3: I let my need to win arguments overshadow friendships and harmony.
personality.@hermit-flaws-4: I’d risk too much to uncover a lost bit of knowledge.
personality.@hermit-flaws-5: I like keeping secrets and won’t share them with anyone.
personality.@knight-traits-0: My eloquent flattery makes everyone I talk to feel like the most wonderful and important person in the world.
personality.@knight-traits-1: The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity.
personality.@knight-traits-2: No one could doubt by looking at my regal bearing that I am a cut above the unwashed masses.
personality.@knight-traits-3: I take great pains to always look my best and follow the latest fashions.
personality.@knight-traits-4: I don’t like to get my hands dirty, and I won’t be caught dead in unsuitable accommodations.
personality.@knight-traits-5: Despite my noble birth, I do not place myself above other folk. We all have the same blood.
personality.@knight-traits-6: My favor, once lost, is lost forever.
personality.@knight-traits-7: If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your fields.
personality.@knight-ideals-0: Respect. Respect is due to me because of my position, but all people regardless of station deserve to be treated with dignity. (Good)
personality.@knight-ideals-1: Responsibility. It is my duty to respect the authority of those above me, just as those below me must respect mine. (Lawful)
personality.@knight-ideals-2: Independence. I must prove that I can handle myself without the coddling of my family. (Chaotic)
personality.@knight-ideals-3: Power. If I can attain more power, no one will tell me what to do. (Evil)
personality.@knight-ideals-4: Family. Blood runs thicker than water. (Any)
personality.@knight-ideals-5: Noble Obligation. It is my duty to protect and care for the people beneath me. (Good)
personality.@knight-bonds-0: I will face any challenge to win the approval of my family.
personality.@knight-bonds-1: My house’s alliance with another noble family must be sustained at all costs.
personality.@knight-bonds-2: Nothing is more important than the other members of my family.
personality.@knight-bonds-3: I am in love with the heir of a family that my family despises.
personality.@knight-bonds-4: My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering.
personality.@knight-bonds-5: The common folk must see me as a hero of the people.
personality.@knight-flaws-0: I secretly believe that everyone is beneath me.
personality.@knight-flaws-1: I hide a truly scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever.
personality.@knight-flaws-2: I too often hear veiled insults and threats in every word addressed to me, and I’m quick to anger.
personality.@knight-flaws-3: I have an insatiable desire for decadent pleasures.
personality.@knight-flaws-4: In fact, the world does revolve around me.
personality.@knight-flaws-5: By my words and actions, I often bring shame to my family.
personality.@noble-traits-0: My eloquent flattery makes everyone I talk to feel like the most wonderful and important person in the world.
personality.@noble-traits-1: The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity.
personality.@noble-traits-2: No one could doubt by looking at my regal bearing that I am a cut above the unwashed masses.
personality.@noble-traits-3: I take great pains to always look my best and follow the latest fashions.
personality.@noble-traits-4: I don’t like to get my hands dirty, and I won’t be caught dead in unsuitable accommodations.
personality.@noble-traits-5: Despite my noble birth, I do not place myself above other folk. We all have the same blood.
personality.@noble-traits-6: My favor, once lost, is lost forever.
personality.@noble-traits-7: If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your fields.

personality.@noble-ideals-1: Responsibility. It is my duty to respect the authority of those above me, just as those below me must respect mine. (Lawful)
personality.@noble-ideals-2: Independence. I must prove that I can handle myself without the coddling of my family. (Chaotic)
personality.@noble-ideals-3: Power. If I can attain more power, no one will tell me what to do. (Evil)
personality.@noble-ideals-4: Family. Blood runs thicker than water. (Any)
personality.@noble-ideals-5: Noble Obligation. It is my duty to protect and care for the people beneath me. (Good)
personality.@noble-bonds-0: I will face any challenge to win the approval of my family.
personality.@noble-bonds-1: My house’s alliance with another noble family must be sustained at all costs.
personality.@noble-bonds-2: Nothing is more important than the other members of my family.
personality.@noble-bonds-3: I am in love with the heir of a family that my family despises.
personality.@noble-bonds-4: My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering.
personality.@noble-bonds-5: The common folk must see me as a hero of the people.
personality.@noble-flaws-0: I secretly believe that everyone is beneath me.
personality.@noble-flaws-1: I hide a truly scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever.
personality.@noble-flaws-2: I too often hear veiled insults and threats in every word addressed to me, and I’m quick to anger.
personality.@noble-flaws-3: I have an insatiable desire for decadent pleasures.
personality.@noble-flaws-4: In fact, the world does revolve around me.
personality.@noble-flaws-5: By my words and actions, I often bring shame to my family.
personality.@outlander-traits-0: I’m driven by a wanderlust that led me away from home.
personality.@outlander-traits-1: I watch over my friends as if they were a litter of newborn pups.
personality.@outlander-traits-2: I once ran twenty-five miles without stopping to warn to my clan of an approaching orc horde. I’d do it again if I had to.
personality.@outlander-traits-3: I have a lesson for every situation, drawn from observing nature.
personality.@outlander-traits-4: I place no stock in wealthy or well-mannered folk. Money and manners won’t save you from a hungry owlbear.
personality.@outlander-traits-5: I’m always picking things up, absently fiddling with them, and sometimes accidentally breaking them.
personality.@outlander-traits-6: I feel far more comfortable around animals than people.
personality.@outlander-traits-7: I was, in fact, raised by wolves.
personality.@outlander-ideals-0: Change. Life is like the seasons, in constant change, and we must change with it. (Chaotic)
personality.@outlander-ideals-1: Greater Good. It is each person’s responsibility to make the most happiness for the whole tribe. (Good)
personality.@outlander-ideals-2: Honor. If I dishonor myself, I dishonor my whole clan. (Lawful)
personality.@outlander-ideals-3: Might. The strongest are meant to rule. (Evil)
personality.@outlander-ideals-4: Nature. The natural world is more important than all the constructs of civilization. (Neutral)
personality.@outlander-ideals-5: Glory. I must earn glory in battle, for myself and my clan. (Any)
personality.@outlander-bonds-0: My family, clan, or tribe is the most important thing in my life, even when they are far from me.
personality.@outlander-bonds-1: An injury to the unspoiled wilderness of my home is an injury to me.
personality.@outlander-bonds-2: I will bring terrible wrath down on the evildoers who destroyed my homeland.
personality.@outlander-bonds-3: I am the last of my tribe, and it is up to me to ensure their names enter legend.
personality.@outlander-bonds-4: I suffer awful visions of a coming disaster and will do anything to prevent it.
personality.@outlander-bonds-5: It is my duty to provide children to sustain my tribe.
personality.@outlander-flaws-0: I am too enamored of ale, wine, and other intoxicants.
personality.@outlander-flaws-1: There’s no room for caution in a life lived to the fullest.
personality.@outlander-flaws-2: I remember every insult I’ve received and nurse a silent resentment toward anyone who’s ever wronged me.
personality.@outlander-flaws-3: I am slow to trust members of other races, tribes, and societies.
personality.@outlander-flaws-4: Violence is my answer to almost any challenge.
personality.@outlander-flaws-5: Don’t expect me to save those who can’t save themselves. It is nature’s way that the strong thrive and the weak perish.
personality.@pirate-traits-0: My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what.
personality.@pirate-traits-1: I work hard so that I can play hard when the work is done.
personality.@pirate-traits-2: I enjoy sailing into new ports and making new friends over a flagon of ale.
personality.@pirate-traits-3: I stretch the truth for the sake of a good story.
personality.@pirate-traits-4: To me, a tavern brawl is a nice way to get to know a new city.
personality.@pirate-traits-5: I never pass up a friendly wager.
personality.@pirate-traits-6: My language is as foul as an otyugh nest.
personality.@pirate-traits-7: I like a job well done, especially if I can convince someone else to do it.
personality.@pirate-ideals-0: Respect. The thing that keeps a ship together is mutual respect between captain and crew. (Good)
personality.@pirate-ideals-1: Fairness. We all do the work, so we all share in the rewards. (Lawful)
personality.@pirate-ideals-2: Freedom. The sea is freedom—the freedom to go anywhere and do anything. (Chaotic)
personality.@pirate-ideals-3: Mastery. I’m a predator, and the other ships on the sea are my prey. (Evil)
personality.@pirate-ideals-4: People. I’m committed to my crewmates, not to ideals. (Neutral)
personality.@pirate-ideals-5: Aspiration. Someday I’ll own my own ship and chart my own destiny. (Any)
personality.@pirate-bonds-0: I’m loyal to my captain first, everything else second.
personality.@pirate-bonds-1: The ship is most important—crewmates and captains come and go.
personality.@pirate-bonds-2: I’ll always remember my first ship.
personality.@pirate-bonds-3: In a harbor town, I have a paramour whose eyes nearly stole me from the sea.
personality.@pirate-bonds-4: I was cheated out of my fair share of the profits, and I want to get my due.
personality.@pirate-bonds-5: Ruthless pirates murdered my captain and crewmates, plundered our ship, and left me to die. Vengeance will be mine.
personality.@pirate-flaws-0: I follow orders, even if I think they’re wrong.
personality.@pirate-flaws-1: I’ll say anything to avoid having to do extra work.
personality.@pirate-flaws-2: Once someone questions my courage, I never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.
personality.@pirate-flaws-3: Once I start drinking, it’s hard for me to stop.
personality.@pirate-flaws-4: I can’t help but pocket loose coins and other trinkets I come across.
personality.@pirate-flaws-5: My pride will probably lead to my destruction.
personality.@sage-traits-0: I use polysyllabic words that convey the impression of great erudition.
personality.@sage-traits-1: I’ve read every book in the world’s greatest libraries—or I like to boast that I have.
personality.@sage-traits-2: I’m used to helping out those who aren’t as smart as I am, and I patiently explain anything and everything to others.
personality.@sage-traits-3: There’s nothing I like more than a good mystery.
personality.@sage-traits-4: I’m willing to listen to every side of an argument before I make my own judgment.
personality.@sage-traits-5: I … speak … slowly … when talking … to idiots, … which … almost … everyone … is … compared … to me.
personality.@sage-traits-6: I am horribly, horribly awkward in social situations.
personality.@sage-traits-7: I’m convinced that people are always trying to steal my secrets.
personality.@sage-ideals-0: Knowledge. The path to power and self-improvement is through knowledge. (Neutral)
personality.@sage-ideals-1: Beauty. What is beautiful points us beyond itself toward what is true. (Good)
personality.@sage-ideals-2: Logic. Emotions must not cloud our logical thinking. (Lawful)
personality.@sage-ideals-3: No Limits. Nothing should fetter the infinite possibility inherent in all existence. (Chaotic)
personality.@sage-ideals-4: Power. Knowledge is the path to power and domination. (Evil)
personality.@sage-ideals-5: Self-Improvement. The goal of a life of study is the betterment of oneself. (Any)
personality.@sage-bonds-0: It is my duty to protect my students.
personality.@sage-bonds-1: I have an ancient text that holds terrible secrets that must not fall into the wrong hands.
personality.@sage-bonds-2: I work to preserve a library, university, scriptorium, or monastery.
personality.@sage-bonds-3: My life’s work is a series of tomes related to a specific field of lore.
personality.@sage-bonds-4: I’ve been searching my whole life for the answer to a certain question.
personality.@sage-bonds-5: I sold my soul for knowledge. I hope to do great deeds and win it back.
personality.@sage-flaws-0: I am easily distracted by the promise of information.
personality.@sage-flaws-1: Most people scream and run when they see a demon. I stop and take notes on its anatomy.
personality.@sage-flaws-2: Unlocking an ancient mystery is worth the price of a civilization.
personality.@sage-flaws-3: I overlook obvious solutions in favor of complicated ones.
personality.@sage-flaws-4: I speak without really thinking through my words, invariably insulting others.
personality.@sage-flaws-5: I can’t keep a secret to save my life, or anyone else’s.
personality.@sailor-traits-0: My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what.
personality.@sailor-traits-1: I work hard so that I can play hard when the work is done.
personality.@sailor-traits-2: I enjoy sailing into new ports and making new friends over a flagon of ale.
personality.@sailor-traits-3: I stretch the truth for the sake of a good story.
personality.@sailor-traits-4: To me, a tavern brawl is a nice way to get to know a new city.
personality.@sailor-traits-5: I never pass up a friendly wager.
personality.@sailor-traits-6: My language is as foul as an otyugh nest.
personality.@sailor-traits-7: I like a job well done, especially if I can convince someone else to do it.
personality.@sailor-ideals-0: Respect. The thing that keeps a ship together is mutual respect between captain and crew. (Good)
personality.@sailor-ideals-1: Fairness. We all do the work, so we all share in the rewards. (Lawful)
personality.@sailor-ideals-2: Freedom. The sea is freedom—the freedom to go anywhere and do anything. (Chaotic)
personality.@sailor-ideals-3: Mastery. I’m a predator, and the other ships on the sea are my prey. (Evil)
personality.@sailor-ideals-4: People. I’m committed to my crewmates, not to ideals. (Neutral)
personality.@sailor-ideals-5: Aspiration. Someday I’ll own my own ship and chart my own destiny. (Any)
personality.@sailor-bonds-0: I’m loyal to my captain first, everything else second.
personality.@sailor-bonds-1: The ship is most important—crewmates and captains come and go.
personality.@sailor-bonds-2: I’ll always remember my first ship.
personality.@sailor-bonds-3: In a harbor town, I have a paramour whose eyes nearly stole me from the sea.
personality.@sailor-bonds-4: I was cheated out of my fair share of the profits, and I want to get my due.
personality.@sailor-bonds-5: Ruthless pirates murdered my captain and crewmates, plundered our ship, and left me to die. Vengeance will be mine.
personality.@sailor-flaws-0: I follow orders, even if I think they’re wrong.
personality.@sailor-flaws-1: I’ll say anything to avoid having to do extra work.
personality.@sailor-flaws-2: Once someone questions my courage, I never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.
personality.@sailor-flaws-3: Once I start drinking, it’s hard for me to stop.
personality.@sailor-flaws-4: I can’t help but pocket loose coins and other trinkets I come across.
personality.@sailor-flaws-5: My pride will probably lead to my destruction.
personality.@soldier-traits-1: I’m haunted by memories of war. I can’t get the images of violence out of my mind.
personality.@soldier-traits-2: I’ve lost too many friends, and I’m slow to make new ones.
personality.@soldier-traits-3: I’m full of inspiring and cautionary tales from my military experience relevant to almost every combat situation.
personality.@soldier-traits-4: I can stare down a hell hound without flinching.
personality.@soldier-traits-5: I enjoy being strong and like breaking things.
personality.@soldier-traits-6: I have a crude sense of humor.
personality.@soldier-traits-7: I face problems head-on. A simple, direct solution is the best path to success.
personality.@soldier-ideals-0: Greater Good. Our lot is to lay down our lives in defense of others. (Good)
personality.@soldier-ideals-1: Responsibility. I do what I must and obey just authority. (Lawful)
personality.@soldier-ideals-2: Independence. When people follow orders blindly, they embrace a kind of tyranny. (Chaotic)
personality.@soldier-ideals-3: Might. In life as in war, the stronger force wins. (Evil)
personality.@soldier-ideals-4: Live and Let Live. Ideals aren’t worth killing over or going to war for. (Neutral)
personality.@soldier-ideals-5: Nation. My city, nation, or people are all that matter. (Any)
personality.@soldier-bonds-0: I would still lay down my life for the people I served with.
personality.@soldier-bonds-1: Someone saved my life on the battlefield. To this day, I will never leave a friend behind.
personality.@soldier-bonds-3: I’ll never forget the crushing defeat my company suffered or the enemies who dealt it.
personality.@soldier-bonds-4: Those who fight beside me are those worth dying for.
personality.@soldier-bonds-5: I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
personality.@soldier-flaws-0: The monstrous enemy we faced in battle still leaves me quivering with fear.
personality.@soldier-flaws-1: I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
personality.@soldier-flaws-2: I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives—and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
personality.@soldier-flaws-3: My hatred of my enemies is blind and unreasoning.
personality.@soldier-flaws-4: I obey the law, even if the law causes misery.
personality.@soldier-flaws-5: I’d rather eat my armor than admit when I’m wrong.
personality.@urchin-traits-0: I hide scraps of food and trinkets away in my pockets.
personality.@urchin-traits-1: I ask a lot of questions.
personality.@urchin-traits-2: I like to squeeze into small places where no one else can get to me.
personality.@urchin-traits-3: I sleep with my back to a wall or tree, with everything I own wrapped in a bundle in my arms.
personality.@urchin-traits-4: I eat like a pig and have bad manners.
personality.@urchin-traits-5: I think anyone who’s nice to me is hiding evil intent.
personality.@urchin-traits-7: I bluntly say what other people are hinting at or hiding.
personality.@urchin-ideals-0: Respect. All people, rich or poor, deserve respect. (Good)
personality.@urchin-ideals-1: Community. We have to take care of each other, because no one else is going to do it. (Lawful)
personality.@urchin-ideals-2: Change. The low are lifted up, and the high and mighty are brought down. Change is the nature of things. (Chaotic)
personality.@urchin-ideals-3: Retribution. The rich need to be shown what life and death are like in the gutters. (Evil)
personality.@urchin-ideals-4: People. I help the people who help me — that’s what keeps us alive. (Neutral)
personality.@urchin-ideals-5: Aspiration. I’m going to prove that I’m worthy of a better life.
personality.@urchin-bonds-0: My town or city is my home, and I’ll fight to defend it.
personality.@urchin-bonds-1: I sponsor an orphanage to keep others from enduring what I was forced to endure.
personality.@urchin-bonds-2: I owe my survival to another urchin who taught me to live on the streets.
personality.@urchin-bonds-3: I owe a debt I can never repay to the person who took pity on me.
personality.@urchin-bonds-4: I escaped my life of poverty by robbing an important person, and I’m wanted for it.
personality.@urchin-bonds-5: No one else should have to endure the hardships I’ve been through.
personality.@urchin-flaws-0: If I’m outnumbered, I will run away from a fight.
personality.@urchin-flaws-1: Gold seems like a lot of money to me, and I’ll do just about anything for more of it.
personality.@urchin-flaws-2: I will never fully trust anyone other than myself.
personality.@urchin-flaws-3: I’d rather kill someone in their sleep than fight fair.
personality.@urchin-flaws-4: It’s not stealing if I need it more than someone else.
personality.@urchin-flaws-5: People who can’t take care of themselves get what they deserve.

adventures.@adventures-0: You nearly died. You have nasty scars on your body, and you are missing an ear, 1d3 fingers, or 1d4 toes.
adventures.@adventures-1: You suffered a grievous injury. Although the wound healed, it still pains you from time to time.
adventures.@adventures-2: You were wounded, but in time you fully recovered.
adventures.@adventures-3: You contracted a disease while exploring a filthy warren. You recovered from the disease, but you have a persistent cough, pockmarks on your skin, or prematurely gray hair.
adventures.@adventures-4: You were poisoned by a trap or a monster. You recovered, but the next time you must make a saving throw against poison, you make the saving throw with disadvantage.
adventures.@adventures-5: You lost something of sentimental value to you during your adventure. Remove one trinket from your possessions.
adventures.@adventures-6: You were terribly frightened by something you encountered and ran away, abandoning your companions to their fate.
adventures.@adventures-7: You learned a great deal during your adventure. The next time you make an ability check or a saving throw, you have advantage on the roll.
adventures.@adventures-8: You found some treasure on your adventure. You have 2d6 gp left from your share of it.
adventures.@adventures-9: You found a considerable amount of treasure on your adventure. You have 1d20 + 50 gp left from your share of it.
adventures.@adventures-10: You came across a common magic item (of the DM’s choice).

arcanematters.@arcanematters-0: You were charmed or frightened by a spell.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-1: You were injured by the effect of a spell.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-2: You witnessed a powerful spell being cast by a cleric, a druid, a sorcerer, a warlock, or a wizard.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-3: You drank a potion (of the DM’s choice).
arcanematters.@arcanematters-4: You found a spell scroll (of the DM’s choice) and succeeded in casting the spell it contained.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-5: You were affected by teleportation magic.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-6: You turned invisible for a time.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-7: You identified an illusion for what it was.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-8: You saw a creature being conjured by magic.
arcanematters.@arcanematters-9: Your fortune was read by a diviner. Roll twice on the Life Events table, but don’t apply the results. Instead, the DM picks one event as a portent of your future (which might or might not come true).

boons.@boons-0: A friendly wizard gave you a spell scroll containing one cantrip (of the DM’s choice).
boons.@boons-1: You saved the life of a commoner, who now owes you a life debt. This individual accompanies you on your travels and performs mundane tasks for you, but will leave if neglected, abused, or imperiled. Determine details about this character by using the supplemental tables and working with your DM.
boons.@boons-3: You found some money. You have 1d20 gp in addition to your regular starting funds.
boons.@boons-4: A relative bequeathed you a simple weapon of your choice.
boons.@boons-5: You found something interesting. You gain one additional trinket.
boons.@boons-6: You once performed a service for a local temple. The next time you visit the temple, you can receive healing up to your hit point maximum.
boons.@boons-7: A friendly alchemist gifted you with a potion of healing or a flask of acid, as you choose.
boons.@boons-9: A distant relative left you a stipend that enables you to live at the comfortable lifestyle for 1d20 years. If you choose to live at a higher lifestyle, you reduce the price of the lifestyle by 2 gp during that time period.

punishment.@punishment-0: You did not commit the crime and were exonerated after being accused.
punishment.@punishment-1: You committed the crime or helped do so, but nonetheless the authorities found you not guilty.
punishment.@punishment-2: You were nearly caught in the act. You had to flee and are wanted in the community where the crime occurred.
punishment.@punishment-3: You were caught and convicted. You spent time in jail, chained to an oar, or performing hard labor. You served a sentence of 1d4 years or succeeded in escaping after that much time.

supernaturalevents.@supernatural-0: You were ensorcelled by a fey and enslaved for 1d6 years before you escaped.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-1: You saw a demon and ran away before it could do anything to you.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-2: A devil tempted you. Make a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, your alignment shifts one step toward evil (if it’s not evil already), and you start the game with an additional 1d20 + 50 gp.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-3: You woke up one morning miles from your home, with no idea how you got there.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-4: You visited a holy site and felt the presence of the divine there.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-5: You witnessed a falling red star, a face appearing in the frost, or some other bizarre happening. You are certain that it was an omen of some sort.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-6: You escaped certain death and believe it was the intervention of a god that saved you.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-8: You explored an empty house and found it to be haunted.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-9: You were briefly possessed. Roll a d6 to determine what type of creature possessed you: 1, celestial; 2, devil; 3, demon; 4, fey; 5, elemental; 6, undead.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-11: You saw a ghoul feeding on a corpse.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-12: A celestial or a fiend visited you in your dreams to give a warning of dangers to come.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-13: You briefly visited the Feywild or the Shadowfell.
supernaturalevents.@supernatural-14: You saw a portal that you believe leads to another plane of existence.

tragedies.@tragedies-0: A family member or a close friend died. Roll on the Cause of Death supplemental table to find out how.
tragedies.@tragedies-1: A friendship ended bitterly, and the other person is now hostile to you. The cause might have been a misunderstanding or something you or the former friend did.
tragedies.@tragedies-2: You lost all your possessions in a disaster, and you had to rebuild your life.
tragedies.@tragedies-3: You were imprisoned for a crime you didn’t commit and spent 1d6 years at hard labor, in jail, or shackled to an oar in a slave galley.
tragedies.@tragedies-4: War ravaged your home community, reducing everything to rubble and ruin. In the aftermath, you either helped your town rebuild or moved somewhere else.
tragedies.@tragedies-5: A lover disappeared without a trace. You have been looking for that person ever since.
tragedies.@tragedies-6: A terrible blight in your home community caused crops to fail, and many starved. You lost a sibling or some other family member.
tragedies.@tragedies-7: You did something that brought terrible shame to you in the eyes of your family. You might have been involved in a scandal, dabbled in dark magic, or offended someone important. The attitude of your family members toward you becomes indifferent at best, though they might eventually forgive you.
tragedies.@tragedies-8: For a reason you were never told, you were exiled from your community. You then either wandered in the wilderness for a time or promptly found a new place to live.
tragedies.@tragedies-9: A romantic relationship ended. Roll a d6. An odd number means it ended with bad feelings, while an even number means it ended amicably.
tragedies.@tragedies-10: A current or prospective romantic partner of yours died. Roll on the Cause of Death supplemental table to find out how. If the result is murder, roll a d12. On a 1, you were responsible, whether directly or indirectly.

war.@war-0: You were knocked out and left for dead. You woke up hours later with no recollection of the battle.
war.@war-1: You were badly injured in the fight, and you still bear the awful scars of those wounds.
war.@war-2: You ran away from the battle to save your life, but you still feel shame for your cowardice.
war.@war-3: You suffered only minor injuries, and the wounds all healed without leaving scars.
war.@war-4: You survived the battle, but you suffer from terrible nightmares in which you relive the experience.
war.@war-5: You escaped the battle unscathed, though many of your friends were injured or lost.
war.@war-6: You acquitted yourself well in battle and are remembered as a hero. You might have received a medal for your bravery.

weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-0: You were turned into a toad and remained in that form for 1d4 weeks.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-1: You were petrified and remained a stone statue for a time until someone freed you.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-2: You were enslaved by a hag, a satyr, or some other being and lived in that creature’s thrall for 1d6 years.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-3: A dragon held you as a prisoner for 1d4 months until adventurers killed it.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-4: You were taken captive by a race of evil humanoids such as drow, kuo-toa, or quaggoths. You lived as a slave in the Underdark until you escaped.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-5: You served a powerful adventurer as a hireling. You have only recently left that service. Use the supplemental tables and work with your DM to determine the basic details about your former employer.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-6: You went insane for 1d6 years and recently regained your sanity. A tic or some other bit of odd behavior might linger.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-7: A lover of yours was secretly a silver dragon.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-8: You were captured by a cult and nearly sacrificed on an altar to the foul being the cultists served. You escaped, but you fear they will find you.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-9: You met a demigod, an archdevil, an archfey, a demon lord, or a titan, and you lived to tell the tale.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-10: You were swallowed by a giant fish and spent a month in its gullet before you escaped.
weirdstuff.@weirdstuff-11: A powerful being granted you a wish, but you squandered it on something frivolous.

lifeevents.@events-0: You suffered a tragedy. Roll on the Tragedies table.
lifeevents.@events-1: You gained a bit of good fortune. Roll on the Boons table.
lifeevents.@events-2: You fell in love or got married. If you get this result more than once, you can choose to have a child instead. Work with your DM to determine the identity of your love interest.
lifeevents.@events-3: You made an enemy of an adventurer. Roll a d6. An odd number indicates you are to blame for the rift, and an even number indicates you are blameless. Use the supplemental tables and work with your DM to determine this hostile character’s identity and the danger this enemy poses to you.
lifeevents.@events-4: You made a friend of an adventurer. Use the supplemental tables and work with your DM to add more detail to this friendly character and establish how your friendship began.
lifeevents.@events-5: You spent time working in a job related to your background. Start the game with an extra 2d6 gp.
lifeevents.@events-6: You met someone important. Use the supplemental tables to determine this character’s identity and how this individual feels about you. Work out additional details with your DM as needed to fit this character into your backstory.
lifeevents.@events-7: You went on an adventure. Roll on the Adventures table to see what happened to you. Work with your DM to determine the nature of the adventure and the creatures you encountered.
lifeevents.@events-8: You had a supernatural experience. Roll on the Supernatural Events table to find out what it was.
lifeevents.@events-9: You fought in a battle. Roll on the War table to learn what happened to you. Work with your DM to come up with the reason for the battle and the factions involved. It might have been a small conflict between your community and a band of orcs, or it could have been a major battle in a larger war.
lifeevents.@events-10: You committed a crime or were wrongly accused of doing so. Roll on the Crime table to determine the nature of the offense and on the Punishment table to see what became of you.
lifeevents.@events-11: You encountered something magical. Roll on the Arcane Matters table.
lifeevents.@events-12: Something truly strange happened to you. Roll on the Weird Stuff table.

causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-3: Accident related to class or occupation
causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-4: Accident unrelated to class or occupation
causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-5: Natural causes, such as disease or old age
causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-7: Torn apart by an animal or a natural disaster
causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-9: Executed for a crime or tortured to death
causeofdeath.@causeofdeath-10: Bizarre event, such as being hit by a meteorite, struck down by an angry god, or killed by a hatching slaad egg
